Award.AwardTitle: 3D Finite Element Analysis of Ultimate Capacity of Suction Caissons under Multi-line Loading

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Development of ocean energy sources is significant to the current U.S. renewable energy and energy independence strategy. Geotechnical site investigation and foundation design are critical, and often costly, aspects of offshore development, however are subject to risks and uncertainties associated with design forces from the dynamic ocean environment and heterogeneous seafloor geology. Consequently, geotechnical issues have been a key factor in delays and cost overruns for some European offshore wind farms. This research seeks to reduce barriers to offshore renewable energy development associated with design and construction of foundation systems for floating technologies such as tidal, wave, ocean current, and deep water wind through advancement of a novel integrated foundation system for multi-device developments. This novel system is comprised of a network of interconnected suction caissons, which are large diameter, hollow cylinder, closed cap, pile-type foundations named for their installation by internal underpressure (i.e., suction) developed during pumping of water from the gap formed between the seafloor and cap. When used in an interconnected network to moor multiple devices, suction caissons have the potential to significantly alleviate development costs by reducing the total number of installed foundations.

This goal of this research is develop the basic engineering knowledge necessary to transform the use of offshore suction caissons in clay soils from single to networked, multi-line mooring anchors. This research will lead to development of three dimensional numerical models used to predict ultimate capacity and deformation of a suction caisson under taut, orthogonal multi-line loading. The models will be calibrated/validated using both published literature and results from a physical modeling study of multi-line caisson behavior under monotonic and cyclic loading previously conducted by the principal investigator. The model will be further developed to investigate the effects of vertical load attachment point, number of lines and radial attachment angles, and load inclination with respect to caisson height on predicted capacity. This research effort will result in numerical modeling and analysis tools that will allow for continued investigation of multi-line loaded suction caisson capacity for a variety of offshore applications.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over 60% of the estimated 450 GW of U.S. offshore wind energy potential is in water depths greater than 60 m where floating platforms are more cost effective. A typical floating platform can require 3 to 4 mooring lines, each with an anchoring foundation. This project represents the start of comprehensive research aimed to study the potential to create a network of interconnected foundations where a single foundation can anchor a single mooring line from multiple floating platforms to make these installations more cost efficient. The broader impact of this research is to reduce cost barriers to ocean renewable energy development that are related to geotechnical site investigations and foundation design and installation, while the technical impact of this research is to investigate the significant extension of current suction caisson design to more than one mooring line.

This study focused specifically on numerical simulation of the suction caisson foundation performance under typical loading conditions in soft clay soils. Suction caissons are suitable for, and have been deployed in, a wide range of seabed soils, and soft clays soils exist worldwide and in locations where offshore energy has been and is planning to be developed and they have been studied extensively by researchers investigating soil-foundation interaction. Suction caissons are essentially upside down buckets, whose walls penetrate the seafloor under their own weight followed by removal of water inside the caisson by pumping until the top of the caisson is near flush with the seafloor. They are typically designed to anchor a single mooring line from one platform, and the wealth of design guidelines and research and performance data reported in the literature will assist in validation of a design using two mooring lines (Figure 1).

A numerical model of the suction caisson with a single mooring line in clay soil was created using commercial Abaqus numerical simulation software and validated based on numerical modeling, soil properties, physical modeling and field performance data under known loading and performance conditions the literature. The numerical model was extended to include two mooring lines and validated based on the work of Chung (2012). The model was then used to investigate the ultimate capacity (or maximum load that could be applied) to one or both lines during a series of loading scenarios under a few different geometric conditions: 1. Loading of line 1 (L1) and line 2 (L2) simultaneously to ultimate; 2. L1 sustained at a load between 27%, 54%, and 81% of the peak while L2 (at 90 degrees to L1) was loaded to ultimate; 3. Loading of L1 and L2 at attachment points different from the design optimal case.

Single line (the standard) and double line loaded ultimate capacities were compared, where the double line results were analyzed for each line individually and the resolution of the two lines based on the angle between them. For simultaneous loading and for L1 sustained and L2 loaded to ultimate, results showed that while the ultimate load capacity for each individual line decreased, the resolved ultimate capacity of the suction caisson was nearly the same as for the single line condition when all loading was from the design optimal attachment point (Figure 2). This indicates that the caisson should be designed for the anticipated combined loading and load angle between the lines in a multi-line scenarios. Strain contours (e.g. deformation) in the soil surrounding the caisson were similar for the single and double line simultaneous loaded cases.however, a difference was seen in the strain contours in the soil surrounding the caisson (Figure 3), where more soil around the diameter of the caisson is influenced. It is most practical to have a fixed load application point on the caisson, and this point is dependent on the angle of load inclination with respect to the...
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Over 60% of the estimated 450 GW of U.S. offshore wind energy potential is in water depths greater than 60 m where floating platforms are more cost effective. A typical floating platform can require 3 to 4 mooring lines, each with an anchoring foundation. This project represents the start of comprehensive research aimed to study the potential to create a network of interconnected foundations where a single foundation can anchor a single mooring line from multiple floating platforms to make these installations more cost efficient. The broader impact of this research is to reduce cost barriers to ocean renewable energy development that are related to geotechnical site investigations and foundation design and installation, while the technical impact of this research is to investigate the significant extension of current suction caisson design to more than one mooring line. This study focused specifically on numerical simulation of the suction caisson foundation performance under typical loading conditions in soft clay soils. Suction caissons are suitable for, and have been deployed in, a wide range of seabed soils, and soft clays soils exist worldwide and in locations where offshore energy has been and is planning to be developed and they have been studied extensively by researchers investigating soil-foundation interaction. Suction caissons are essentially upside down buckets, whose walls penetrate the seafloor under their own weight followed by removal of water inside the caisson by pumping until the top of the caisson is near flush with the seafloor. They are typically designed to anchor a single mooring line from one platform, and the wealth of design guidelines and research and performance data reported in the literature will assist in validation of a design using two mooring lines (Figure 1). A numerical model of the suction caisson with a single mooring line in clay soil was created using commercial Abaqus numerical simulation software and validated based on numerical modeling, soil properties, physical modeling and field performance data under known loading and performance conditions the literature. The numerical model was extended to include two mooring lines and validated based on the work of Chung (2012). The model was then used to investigate the ultimate capacity (or maximum load that could be applied) to one or both lines during a series of loading scenarios under a few different geometric conditions: 1. Loading of line 1 (L1) and line 2 (L2) simultaneously to ultimate; 2. L1 sustained at a load between 27%, 54%, and 81% of the peak while L2 (at 90 degrees to L1) was loaded to ultimate; 3. Loading of L1 and L2 at attachment points different from the design optimal case. Single line (the standard) and double line loaded ultimate capacities were compared, where the double line results were analyzed for each line individually and the resolution of the two lines based on the angle between them. For simultaneous loading and for L1 sustained and L2 loaded to ultimate, results showed that while the ultimate load capacity for each individual line decreased, the resolved ultimate capacity of the suction caisson was nearly the same as for the single line condition when all loading was from the design optimal attachment point (Figure 2). This indicates that the caisson should be designed for the anticipated combined loading and load angle between the lines in a multi-line scenarios. Strain contours (e.g. deformation) in the soil surrounding the caisson were similar for the single and double line simultaneous loaded cases.however, a difference was seen in the strain contours in the soil surrounding the caisson (Figure 3), where more soil around the diameter of the caisson is influenced. It is most practical to have a fixed load application point on the caisson, and this point is dependent on the angle of load inclination with respect to the vertical caisson wall.
